sequence.notes: The reaction shows the formation of a bromohydrin from a terminal alkene (isopropylidene group) using N-bromosuccinimide (NBS). The starting material is a C40 polyisoprenoid chain, where one of the terminal C=C(CH3)2 groups undergoes regioselective and stereoselective addition to form the bromohydrin. All internal double bonds retain their E (trans) stereochemistry. The label 'Omaezakianol (Corey 2010)' typically refers to a C35 compound, which conflicts with the C40 structure visually represented in the screenshot for both reactant and product. The SMILES are generated based on the visual information from the screenshot, assuming a C40 carbon skeleton.
Intramolecular formation of an epoxide from a bromohydrin using a base.

Acid-catalyzed epoxide opening with chloride nucleophile forming a chlorohydrin. The epoxide opens regioselectively, with the chloride attacking the more substituted carbon and the hydroxyl group forming at the less substituted carbon, where a new chiral center is created (indicated by the squiggle bond).
Five internal and terminal alkenes are stereoselectively epoxidized using a Shi catalyst and Oxone.

Formation of hexameric poly-tetrahydrofuran (poly-THF) from an open-chain polyketone precursor via acid-catalyzed cyclization. The stereochemistry of the first chiral carbon in the product is drawn with a wavy bond, indicating unknown or racemic stereochemistry; it is omitted in the SMILES. All other chiral centers are explicitly defined based on the 'bold/dashed' bond depiction for trans relationships.
Sodium-mediated dehalogenative reductive fragmentation of a polyether, resulting in the formation of an isopentenyl chain and a new secondary alcohol.
